text: Family Member: APS. Patient: She came here actually for one of the world experts on APS. Family Member: Yeah. Patient: Which is a blood disorder. Clotting. Doctor: Okay. text: Patient: Right. Doctor: So they don’t want to, uh, subject you to, you know, have a needle stuck in your bone if it’s not going to be helpful. Patient: Right. Doctor: And so, but the trial requires the tissue, because they’re trying to study how the new drug affects the tissue in some way. So let me, let me look into that, uh, to see if any of the trials allow bone only. The only trials we have for hormonal treatment are with Xtandi right now, uh, not with the other drug. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So, if it looks like you can’t, if it looks like you would fit on the trial, we can talk about them more. If, if it looks like the bone thing is going to eliminate that- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Then I would just proceed with the Xtandi and start it. Okay? (Sound Door closes) Patient: Um hum. Doctor: The other piece of this that’s an unknown piece is, we have some sets that the people who got testosterone, even the ones that didn’t respond to it, seemed to have a better response to drugs like Xtandi or Zytiga afterwards. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And our, our idea is maybe that the cells have gotten used to being low testosterone and they’ve kind of adjusted. Then we put them in high testosterone, they adjust to that-

text: Family Member: or is he still gonna feel fatigued and miserable. Doctor: You should feel better. I know it’s counterintuitive. Like wait, you’re poisoning me and you’re telling me I would feel better. I think you feel bad because your cancer is not controlled, Patient: Okay. Doctor: you know, and some people could have a PSA at three thousand and feel better than you. Some people could have a PSA of thirty and feel worse than you. I don’t really care what the number is. I do know that your cancer isn’t treated. So, when you have untreated cancer you just don’t feel good. Patient: Okay, because I like to work outside and do stuff Doctor: Um hum Patient: and I do that but then it seems like the next day, does that have a part to it or no? Family Member: If he overdoes it on one day. Doctor: Oh, of course. Oh, everybody does that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Everybody does that not just you. Patient: Okay. Doctor: You know there’s two philosophies with that which is like oh, if it’s good day I’m gonna max it out so I can veg out the next day and I have some other patients that will just like pace themselves like I know it’s a good day but I don’t want to pay the price the next day so I’ll just moderate myself and then it’s more even. So, it’s really your preference. Some people would just be like I’d rather have one good day out of three rather than my the eh days.

text: Family Member: Xofigo. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: Do you think he’s qualified to go away on a vacation for a couple of weeks? Doctor: Uh hum, yeah – when are you going? text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: Looking at the first scan we did when we first started. The scan we did after enzalutamide. So then we’re back at sort of like this. It sort of looks like we’re staying on. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So things are still growing at a slow to moderate pace, I’d say. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh so yeah I, I, I’m always concerned about that but I don’t think it’s reflective of making it grow more. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Now we have seen folks you know stop the testosterone and PSA goes back down. Some of that elevation is related to, to stimulate production. Patient: Right. Doctor: So you know we’d like to see where, where we go with that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh in terms of once we reboot to be well again. The uh the problem we face is you know looking at the trials there are sort of two levels of looking at what’s available next.

text: Patient: Right. Doctor: So you know with you, you know what I worry about is sometimes you know, we write prostate cancer on the order form so the doctor over says, “Oh, yeah, there it is, there it is.” Patient: Okay. Doctor: And they may be right, or they may be calling what we normally if you had a scan and they’d say, “ that’s just arthritis, that’s just arthritis, that’s just arthritis”. Patient: Right. Doctor: Prostate Cancer likes to go to the lymph nodes, and so they're oft- they have to start small. And so we all have lymph nodes, but in this case, they say yeah, there’s lymph nodes- Patient: Right. Doctor: -there's a lot of them, so that could be cancer. Patient: Right. DOC. They didn't say it was cancer. It could be cancer. Doctor: The stuff in your back Two different modes of how we look at your back are telling us different things about different places. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So the tiebreaker really would be to get another test.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
